message.content:
We can solve the problem by “re‐constructing” a single extended family tree from the given statements and then seeing how Steven and Wayne are related. (Recall that when we say “X is Y’s ancestor,” X comes before Y in the chain; when we say “X is Y’s descendant,” X comes later.)

One way to do this is to “chain‐link” the statements. Two long branches eventually merge at one person. (Below is one way to see the connection.)

One branch (call it the “Wayne branch”) begins as follows:
 • Wayne is Jesse’s ancestor.
 • Jesse is Ruth’s ancestor.
 • Ruth is the ancestor of Sharon (since “Sharon is Ruth’s descendant”).
 • Sharon is the ancestor of Raymond.
 • Raymond is the ancestor of Christopher (“Christopher is Raymond’s descendant”).
 • Christopher is the ancestor of Isabella.
 • Isabella → Ethan → Barbara → Ashley.
 • Then, “Shirley is Ashley’s descendant” (so Ashley is an ancestor of Shirley) and “Shirley is Sean’s ancestor.”
 • Then Sean → Sophia → Jose (since “Sean is Sophia’s ancestor” and “Sophia is Jose’s ancestor”).
 • Then through further links (“Nicholas is Jose’s descendant” then “Amanda is Nicholas’s descendant,” etc.) the branch continues with
  Amanda → Abigail → Harold → Julia → Brian → Frank → Kelly.
 • Then “Kelly is Robert’s ancestor” → Robert → Kenneth → Stephanie → David → Benjamin → Russell → Virginia → Evelyn → Ronald → Jonathan → Charles → Catherine → Jeremy → Betty → Gregory.

The other branch (the “Steven branch”) begins its chain as follows:
 • We know “Aaron is Steven’s descendant” (so Steven is an ancestor of Aaron).
 • Also, “Karen is Aaron’s descendant” (making Steven an ancestor of Karen).
 • “Karen is Albert’s ancestor” → Albert; “Albert is Marilyn’s ancestor” → Marilyn; “Marilyn is Janice’s ancestor” → Janice.
 • Then “Janice is Jennifer’s ancestor” → Jennifer; “Jennifer is Logan’s ancestor” → Logan; “Logan is Jacob’s ancestor” → Jacob; “Jacob is Kathryn’s ancestor” → Kathryn.
 • Then “Kathryn is Maria’s ancestor” → Maria.
 • Next, “Samantha is Maria’s descendant” means Maria is an ancestor of Samantha.
 • And “Samantha is Stephen’s ancestor” (note: Stephen is a different person from Steven) → Stephen.
 • Then “Stephen is Joe’s ancestor” → Joe; “Nathan is Joe’s descendant” (so Joe is an ancestor of Nathan) ; “Nathan is Daniel’s ancestor” → Daniel; “Olivia is Daniel’s descendant” → Olivia; “Patrick is Olivia’s descendant” → Patrick; “Juan is Patrick’s descendant” → Juan; “Marie is Juan’s descendant” → Marie; “Natalie is Marie’s descendant” → Natalie; “Gerald is Natalie’s descendant” → Gerald; “Gerald is Larry’s ancestor” → Larry; “Susan is Larry’s descendant” (so Larry is an ancestor of Susan); “Susan is Alexander’s ancestor” → Alexander; “Alexander is Ralph’s ancestor” → Ralph; “Ralph is Christine’s ancestor” → Christine; and finally “Gregory is Christine’s descendant” (so Christine is an ancestor of Gregory).

Thus, both branches end at Gregory. In other words, starting from Wayne (in the first branch) and from Steven (in the second branch) the “paths” both eventually yield Gregory as a descendant.

Since both Wayne and Steven have Gregory (and in fact many people from that point on) as a descendant, we conclude that:
 Steven and Wayne share a common descendant.

Therefore, the correct answer is option 4.

<ANSWER>4</ANSWER>
